subject: RE: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
msgSnippet: ... Apart from elapsed time exactly the sam output for me. BUT THAT ACTUALLY MEANS THE TEST HAS PASSED (shouting out of shear horror, sorry ;-) I use jdk 1.3.1
messageBody:
> From: Berin Loritsch
>
> Here are my results (JDK 1.3.1)
>
> . Local Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
> . Static Byte: Success means that -128 == -128
> . Class Byte: Success means that -128 > 127
> F. Class Short: Success means that -32768 > 32767
> F
> Time: 0.081
> There were 2 failures:
> 1)
> testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at StrangeByteTest.testByteMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:51)
> 2)
> testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest)junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at StrangeByteTest.testShortMaxValue(StrangeByteTest.java:62)
> FAILURES!!!
> Tests run: 4, Failures: 2, Errors: 0
>
> Question:
>
> What JDK are you running? It appears you have some implicit upcasting
> to a long or something happening.
>
Apart from elapsed time exactly the sam output for me.
BUT THAT ACTUALLY MEANS THE TEST HAS PASSED (shouting out of shear horror,
sorry ;-)
I use jdk 1.3.1 and JUnit 3.7 (although JUnit isn't the problem I guess)
